choices: Let him go get the Captain
Don't let him go get the Captain
1.content:
Catalina aboards her family's ship. Just getting done with college to become a teacher, she's now on her way back to the United States. Her parents want her to become a school teacher, but she would rather
write stories and poems.

The bright sunshine shown through her bedroom
window. She sat up on her cot and looked at
the mohagany desk to her right. She hurried to get dressed. Today she would have lunch with Thomas Kellinger, the Captain's assistant, and also a crush of hers. She gets
into her best dress, and shoes and heads to the deck. Of course, she must have breakfast.

Sitting on deck, and letting the sun shine down on you, and letting the wind blow through your hair is the best way to enjoy the day. Your black curly hair hangs to your lower back. You took it out of your bun so that the wind could blow through it. "You know, I believe you're the first girl I've ever met who has dark hair with bright blue
eyes," Thomas said coming up to the front of
the ship with you. "Thank you Thomas," feeling flattered. "Are you ready for lunch?"
Thomas asked. "Almost. I would just like to rest on the deck if you don't mind," You reply politely. "That's fine with me," he replies leaning against the railing. "What is
that?" You ask looking far off into the distance? "I'm not sure. Let me go get the captain," Thomas replied.
1.title: Homeward Bound

choices: go run and hide
stay and see what happens
go with thomas to the captains cabin
11.content:
You stare worriedly into the distance, a pirate ship? God forbid! As you think back of all the pirate stories you've ever heard, how entire ships are set aflame with the crew on board, and how other crews have been killed through torture, the only remaining traces being a floating body part here or there, what the sharks didn't get, you nervously begin to bite your finger nails. Then remind yoursef of that you promised to give that habit up three years ago.

You look around, where is Thomas? You wish that he, or the captain, or anyone for that matter would come up deck near you to inform you of what is going on.

The ship has drawn nearer during the passing time. You now are able to observe the lack of a flag flying- not a good sign.

You sigh and look around. Surprisingly, the deck is deserted. There isn't a soul around. Alone, and feeling alone, on deck you stand and watch the approaching ship with dread wishing you could melt into the boards or sink beneath the waves.
11.title: worried anticipation

choices: Go and see if anyone can help you
Go back to the closet
111.content:
You run and hide inside a closet. A storage
closet. One used by the spit crew. The people
who clean the decks. You slide to the bottom,
and cover yourself with the mops. They smell
mucky, and like mildew. You hear voices out-
side. They are all muffled, so you can't hear
what anyone is saying.

Soon, everything is quiet. You open the door,
and you don't see anything. You turn left and
walk back on deck. The ship is still there to
your ship, so you crawl on your hands and knees so that they won't see you. Your fear
is so strong inside of you, that in a way,
you wish you were dead.
111.title: Quiet

choices: Go and see who that other body is
Keep going
1111.content:
You begin to crawl towards the captain's cabin. There is no whisper, no noise what-
so-ever. You peek in, and you see two bodies.
They are laying face down on the floor. You
can tell one is the captain's, but you can't
tell who the other body is. A chill creeps
up your spine. A feeling you've never had
before.
1111.title: The bodies

Kick him and run
11111.content:
You crawl up to the body to see who it is. You go onto the other side. You lift the head and gasp. Tears build up in your eyes.
You put your head down and cry. It was Thomas. Your love, your crush, your sweety.
You just wanted to crawl up and die somewhere.

You hear something. It sounds like footprints. You crawl and hide underneath
the bed. You slide and hide near the wall.
"Tylas, come here! I think I heard something
in here! It sounded like crying!" exclaimed
a voice. You hear another set of footprints.
This time they sounded like they were running. "What Hugo? What did you hear?" asked Tylas. "Sounds like cryin! What ever
it was, it didn't leave this room!" Hugo
exclaimed. "Start searchin!" Tylas replied.

You are so scared. You aren't sure what these
people were going to do to you. You've heard
all kinds of stories, of what pirates did
to people. "What was that?" Tylas asked.
"What?" Hugo asked. "I think it came from
under there," Tylas replied. Hugo kneeled on
the floor. He looked under the bed and spots
you.
11111.title: Being Spotted

choices: Stand up against them
Remain quiet
111111.content:
You stay there in total shock. He reaches
his hand underneath, trying to reach your
foot. He grabs it and begins to pull you out.

When you are fully out from under the bed,
the men stare at you. "Who are you, and what
are you doing under there?" One man asks.
111111.title: Out in The Open

choices: Story continues
1111111.content:
You look up at the pirates from your position on the floor. One of the pirates standing over you appears to be on the young side. The arrogant snarl on his face and the muscular arms fisted on his hips leave you no doubt that the innocence of youth had been replaced with the necessity to be tough and perhaps cruel to survive as a pirate. The other man is a bit older, broad in the shoulders and chest, his chocolate-brown hair tied at the nape of his neck with a piece of twine. His expression is unreadable.

You try to regain some of your dignity by standing, only to find that the older pirate still hasn't let go of your ankle. Irritation at his familiarity momentarily overcomes the mingling fear and sorrow you had been feeling moments before. "Unhand me, you brute!" you exclaim, kicking yourself free of his grasp. His eyes narrow, but he releases you and you jump to your feet.

You make a show of brushing the dust bunnies off of your skirts as if this task is more important than addressing the pirates in front of you. The older one stands with an annoyed sigh, towering over you.

"Your name," he repeats.

You look up at him, masking your fear and pain with the cool, collected, upper-class, snobby look you saw so often in England. "My name is Catalina Sherwood. You, of course, may call me Miss Sherwood."

"So, *Miss* Sherwood," he begins, stressing the Miss in a mocking tone, "What is a fine *lady* such as yourself doing on a little boat in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean?"

You manage to mask your surprise at your father's finest ship being called a little boat. "Why, this is my father's *little boat* and I have finished my college education in England and am returning home to the United States," you reply, keeping your eyes cool, your spine straight, and your head held high.

"You mean you *were* on your way to the United States," the younger pirate interrupts. "Hey, Hugo, what do you say we leave this little *lady* here, finish taking over the ship, and then come back for a little fun!"

One look at the leer on the young pirate's face and you are certain you aren't interested in the *fun* he is suggesting. You try to suppress the shudder of revulsion and fear that ripples through you.

"I agree with that part about leaving her here for now," the pirate named Hugo starts, "but I think you'll be leaving this one untouched. If this really is her father's ship, she could be of value for ransom. I can't imagine she'd be of much use after you and your friends would get through with her."

The younger pirate actually smiles proudly as if Hugo has given him a great compliment. This time you can't fully suppress your shudder when he turns to look at you. "Your loss, my pretty little lady," he taunts, undressing you with his eyes. "I'm sure me and the boys could have shown you a real good time before we slit your throat!"

Hugo's expression remains unreadable. "Why don't you get us some rope," he says instead. Without warning, Hugo picks you up, tossing you over his shoulder like a sack of potatoes, and walks across the Captain's cabin. Your struggling, but your aren't even sure if Hugo notices.

To your disgust, he steps over the body of your beloved Thomas as if he wasn't there. Looking down at Thomas' lifeless body from the height of the pirate's shoulder, the sadness wells up inside you anew. By the time you have been uncerimonially tied into the captain's chair, the tears are flowing freely down your face. 'So much for my brave front,' you think in self-disgust.

Your position in the captain's chair gives you a clear view of Thomas. His head is still turned to the side, and his open unseeing eyes are facing you. For the first time you realize that he is lying in a pool of blood and gore. Images from the fun weeks on the boat with Thomas flash through your mind. It seems so unfair that sweet Thomas would end up as such. The injustice brings a fresh flood of tears.

Hugo seems to notice your distress. He bends down and closes Thomas' eyes, and then pulls a blanket off of the Captain's bed, covering the still bodies of Thomas and the Captain. Hugo then turns and faces you. "If I were you, Miss Sherwood," he says in an voice unusually void of emotion, "I would be more worried about your fate than that of your father's men."

And then he is gone.
1111111.title: Meeting the pirates

choices: Scream for Hugo or one of your father's men to save you
Say that you think you contracted the plague in England and they should keep bac
11111111.content:
With the immediate threat of the pirates gone, you test the ropes binding you into the Captain's chair. It is as you expected: if anyone could tie strong knots, it would be a man of the sea. The silence is suffocating, and you find yourself dwelling on the hopelessness of your situation. Your father was losing a great deal of his personal savings in the loss of this ship an his men. It was not guaranteed that he could even come up with whatever ransom the pirates would demand. Even if he could, how much time would go by before the exchange could take place? It would be weeks before anyone even realized the boat hadn't docked on schedule, perhaps weeks later before word would arrive to her father that she was being held for ransom and was not just the victim of a sunken ship. 'This is foolishness,' you try telling yourself. 'You aren't even sure the pirates are going to succeed in taking over the ship!'

You chance a glance at the blanket-covered bodies of your beloved Thomas and the Captain. The cold blood is seeping into the blanket, and the darker spots are widening as the fluid bleeds into the fabric.

Trying to distact yourself from such a gruesome sight and the bodies you know lie beneath the blanket, you force yourself to look at the surface of the Captain's desk in front of you. The surface of the wood is rich and costly. An elegant map lies partially unrolled, showing the intended course of the voyage. Elegant fountain pens sit on the desk, along with an ink well. You start to remember the last letter you had penned to your family: your father, your mother, your kid sister, Mary. You had been so satisfied. You had accomplished the goals your parents had laid out for you -- good education at an English school so she could be not just a school teacher but an elegant school teacher, proper, polite, and neat. More importantly, her parents had hoped that her skills in conversation, music, and culture would make her qualified to be the wife of an upper class man. Her family was, after all, new money, and she had not been raised in the richer class her sister Mary now enjoyed.

Your train of thought is interrupted when you notice a note on the table. You are surprised you didn't notice it earlier. Neat but definately masculine handwriting states the following, obviously refferring to you: "This captive is claimed by me and should be considered under my protection. Abuse her and forfit your life. -Hugo"

You are still sitting there in stunned silence when the first sounds of fighting reach your ears. First there are the bone-chilling cries of the pirate crew as they rush onto your father's ship. There are shouts as your father's crew rush out of their hiding places to meet the attack. Then the shouts are joined by the sounds of metal hitting metal in sword and knife fighting and the occasional explosions from guns. You realize that these sounds are all being muted by the strong wooden walls of the Captain's cabin and that they must be deafening on the deck.

The cries of the injured and dying are chilling to you, and you are just starting to find yourself thankful for your relative safety of the Captain's cabin when the door is opened. The sounds of the battle are louder, and the brighter light from the deck spills across the floor. As your eyes adjust you see two of the ugliest men you have ever seen.

It is obvious to you that they are pirates. One of them leers at you. "Look what someone left for us!" he cries.

The other is also undressing you with his eyes. "Tylas was right. It would be a waste to leave a pretty little thing like this to Hugo and his ransoming idea. Much less trouble to get her value out of her here and now!" He starts to approach you, and his intent is clear.
11111111.title: All Tied Up

choices: You're taken aboard his ship.
111111111.content:
As soon as the men take their first steps toward you, you feel a cry rushing to your lips. But instead of the name of one of your father's sailors, you feel another name escaping your body and mingling with the chaotic noise on deck: "Hugo!"

The name sounds foreign coming from your mouth, and both you and the pirates are fazed for a moment. Unfortunately, the pirates recover first. More hastily than ever they approach you, and within a second they're towering over your helpless bound figure. One takes a moment to give a wretched smile before pinching your waistband with a thumb and forefinger and raising a mean-looking dagger to cut it--and the rest of your clothes--from your body, without much regard for how much skin will get slashed in the process. You close your eyes tight, regretting deeply that you were stupid enough to call for a pirate's help...

But instead of the feel of a blade sweeping down across your stomach, a loud gurgling shriek startles you into opening your eyes. The pirate with the dagger slumps onto the floor, blood pouring from a fresh cut across his throat. Hugo and the other pirate wrestle above the body, and after a quick struggle your other attacker also falls to the floor, wounded although not mortally. His adrenaline spent, Hugo turns to you and quickly cuts you from your bonds and just as quickly captures your wrists in his hands.

"Obviously I have to keep an eye on what's mine." You look at him, infuriated, and he knows exactly what you're thinking. "My money, I mean. You're coming with me. You have no choice." Though his grip is tight as iron cuffs, Hugo's voice is nonchalant. With a harsh tug he leads you out into the sunlight.
111111111.title: A close call

choices: My new quarters
meeting the crew
1111111111.content:
"Why did you call for me?" he asked, his expression giving nothing away as he pulled her up off the chair.

"I-I don't know," I answered shakily, reeling from the death of the crewman who had almost molested me. The other crewman lay on the floor moaning.

"You hamstrung me!" he cried, holding his leg and rolling from side to side.

"Served you right, ya scum!" was Hugo's sharp answer. "You knew she was under my protection!"

"I was just trying to have a little fun!" he whined, and Hugo kicked him in the other leg.

"Shut up!" He turned and looked at me, realizing I hadn't said anything further. I looked up at him with dazed and fearful eyes, not sure I hadn't traded one set of lecherous hands for another. "Are you alright?" His tone of voice was odd, coming a touch gentler than his speaking to the man rolling around on the floor.

I felt my stomach clench in nerves and fear, and tried to nod at the same time. He shook his head at me and pulled me along after him.

"I should have put on board the Northern Star the minute I laid eyes on ya," he muttered, his grip rough against my soft skin.

I stumbled over the legs of the now dead crewman, and cast a last look at Thomas where he lay under the blanket with other dead men. How many had died this day? And for what? What would my father think? Would I ever see my family again?

All the questions going through my mind sent me reeling as we stepped out into the clear bright day. For some reason I thought it would be dark and foggy and a nightmare outside as it had been inside. But it was not. The wind whipped my hair out of it's combs and I looked up at the snapping of the sails.

There were no men tending them, and they were flapping loose and the ship was listing. Little as I knew of the sea from my short voyage, I knew that they were scuttling the ship and leaving on their own. I thought of the cargo in the hold that had been intended for American shores. It would never see the light of day.

Hugo walked quickly, despite the heaving deck, and I was suddenly faced with the prospect of crossing over the waves on a slim board lashed between them.

"I can't go on that!" I cried, my fears overcoming my silence.

"You can if you want to live," was the deep answer, and before I could voice another objection, he picked me up in his arms like a bolt of cloth, and twisting a rope around his other hand, was quickly up and over the board, putting me down on the other heaving deck as if it had been a jump over a barrel.

"Welcome to the Northern Star, Miss Sherwood," he drawled, handing me over to a dark skinned man with dreadlocks hanging past his shoulders.

I promptly fainted.
1111111111.title: Welcome to the Northern Star

choices: Try to untie the ropes again (yeah, right!)
Wait patiently for either the pirates or your father's men to enter.
111111112.content:
You doubt that the sounds of your screams could even be heard over the sounds of the battel, so you decide to handle this situation as logically as possible.

"Wait, don't come any closer..." You start the warning, and then let loose a well-faked fit of coughing. "I don't want... you to get... sick too..." you gasp out between coughs. "Everyone dying... please... no more deaths because of me..."

The looks on the pirates' faces turns quickly from leers to fear. They look hesitantly at each other, wondering if a quick good time at your expense is worth whatever illness you might be harboring.

You decide to take this bluff all the way. "I've been in England..." you wheeze out. "The plague..."

These words are all that are required. The men rush out of the room, slamming the door behind them.

You tell yourself that you would probably feel quite clever for pulling off that scam if you weren't tied to a chair by the bodies of your sweetheart and the Captain of your father's ship while the rest of your father's men battle attacking pirates. Then you realize that the sounds of fighting have faded, and instead you hear the sounds of the cheering of the victors. The question is, who won?
111111112.title: The Sickness

choices: Describe the two men and what they said Tylas had said
Describe the two men but forget to mention Tylas.
1111111121.content:
Feeling a sudden rush of anxiety over the uncertainty of your situation, you try once again to free yourself from the ropes. Your legs are tied at the ankles to the legs of the chairs, and your wrists are tied behind your back with the rope twisted around the wooden slats making up the back of the chair. The struggling with the ropes, which starts tentatively, becomes frantic as frustration at your helplessness sets in. When Hugo walks into the room you are in a frenzy, twisting uselessly in your chair as you try to free your hands.

"Miss Catalina Sherwood," he says in the tone one would use to warn a naughty child. You jump up, startled. You hadn't even heard him enter the Captain's cabin. "You wouldn't be trying to escape, would you?" He steps towards you, stepping over the bodies on the floor and reaching you in a few paces. He tips a finger under your chin and lifts your face up so your eyes meet his. His are cold and expressionless, and a chill runs through you. "I told you that you were valuable to me for ransom. If you had managed to escape and ran into the other pirates, I doubt you would be valuable to me anymore when they would get through with you. So you see, Miss Sherwood, it is in both my best interest and your best interest that you do whatever I say, do you understand?"

You give a frightened nod. You hate being intimidated and useless like this, but he does have a point. You are safer if you stick with this Hugo pirate, who sees you as useful, than you would be to the likes of the other pirates. Especially if they were all like those two you had scared off. But your pride refuses to let you be so easily tamed.

You shake your head defiantly, making his finger slip away from your chin. "Yes, I saw the note you left on the table. I am supposedly under your protection now. I have to wonder, though, how good that protection is going to be?"

His eyes narrow at you in what you might interpret as anger if his face wasn't so irritatingly unreadable. "You're still alive, so my protection is working wonders," he says cooly.

"Yes, I suppose I am..." you start, letting the expected 'but' hang in the air for a moment. "But is it weren't for my own quick wit I would be of no use to you at all right now. While you were off *murdering* my father's men," you are forced to swallow back the sudden lump that enters your throat at the the thougth of those dear men being murdered, "two of your *pirate friends* were in here pondering how much bearing your *claim* of me had on their right to *have a little fun.*"

Now the anger in his face in unmistakable. "Who?" he asked.

"Who?" you ask in return.

"Yes, who? Who dared to doubt my claim?"
1111111121.title: Protection?

choices: Be taken aboard the pirate ship.
11111111211.content:
"They were two of the ugliest men I've seen in my life," you say, disgusted. "One all in green with a puckered scar across his nose, and one with a blonde beard and breath reeking of fish. They said Tylas was right, that there was no reason I needed to be spared for ransom." You spit the words out, remembering their look of pure lechery, and a shiver runs down the back of your neck. Hugo takes everything in ... even the shudder.

"Tylas, then. Well well, my own right hand stabs me in the back. He'll see what that gets him soon enough. And the others would be Orrin and Edric, may they rot in hell." You both take some satisfaction in the curse, but you quickly remember that Hugo wouldn't care a bit for your life or your safety if you were just a poor sailor like Thomas. You look into Hugo's blank brown eyes coldly as he pauses to consider you.

"Well, I suppose I'll have to invest a little in your security, with treacherous bastards like Tylas running loose," he says briskly. Pulling a dagger from its sheath at his hip, he cuts your bonds before grabbing your wrists, holding you where you are. He leans in until his face is an inch from yours, and for the first time you see a bit of fire in his mysterious eyes. "But first things first. You *will* obey me, if you want to live and live well. I didn't kill any of your men, not yet, my job is to find the spoils and you're it. So don't be stupid and try to avenge their deaths by scorning me and ruining your only chance at life, got it, girl?"

You nod, the only thing you can think to do with his eyes so close to your own, and the next thing you know you're being pulled up and out onto the disturbing calm of the bloody deck.
11111111211.title: Naming Tylas

choices: Slap him
Keep going with no reply
111111112111.content:
It didn't matter that *he* didn't kill and of your men, but *his men* must have. You look in horror as you see all of the bodies, some of them pirates.

"Don't look," Hugo whispers into your ear, dangerously close, "or you'll just get more upset."

As if you could get more upset! You keep your face forward and walk at a measured pace. You don't answer and try to fight tears.

"That's a girl," Hugo whispers into your ear again. "You just be a good girl and don't give me any trouble and things will always go this nice."
111111112111.title: Be taken aboard the pirate ship.

He murmurs something to himself and then speaks clearly to her. “Did they say anything else?” Tylas seems a threat to mention but you shake your head and hold your tongue. “Well that's good I'll make sure these two men clean up the *plagued* bodies and then slit their throats.” he turns toward the door and you cry out.
“Shouldn't I be placed some where else in case they don't believe it a second time?” you ask mainly from the sickening thought that Thomas was still there dead under the sheets which has barely kept you from seeing all the blood.
“Perhaps.”

the ship your on is sinking

Move around so he can't be able to

You decide to give a false identification and to try to impress upon the pirates
1111112.content:
When you are fully out from under the bed,
the men stare at you. "Who are you, and what
are you doing under there?" One man asks.

You look up at the two men from your position on the floor, but you don't really see them. You had heard before that sometimes, in a really traumatic experience, a person will seem to leave their body, to witness their life as if they were only an outsider and not a participant. As you look through the pirates, you find yourself marveling at the irony -- your parents had tried so hard to set your future in stone, even going so far as to send you to England to teach you to be a proper, polite, and neat school teacher. You meekly followed the course they charted for your life, studying hard to be both the perfect teacher and the model upper-class daughter. You could take tea with the best of them; you knew the geography of all territories of interest to the United States and England; you could play the sweetest melodies on the violin and write elegantly in flourished handwriting. And now you are on your father's boat in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean, all of your protectors have been killed, and your desitny is in the hands of a bunch of pirates. You want to both cry and laugh at the irony.

You must have smiled wryly during your mental monologue, because when you refocus your eyes on the pirates, they are looking at you as if you are quite daft. You decide that is just as well. 'Maybe if they think you are daft you will have a better chance of planning an escape,' you wonder, 'If they don't kill you right now,' you add to yourself.

One of the pirates is standing, and you notice that he is younger than you would have expected, muscular in the arms but quite a bit narrower in the chest and shoulders than a full-grown man. His clothing are a bit on the ratty side. You can't help but notice the blood splattered on his shirt, and vagely wonder if it is his. The other pirate is definately a full-grown man, with longer black hair tied back at the nape of his neck. His face is obscured by a thick black beard. His eyes, a piercing blue in the rich tan of his face, are watching you closely. He is squatting down near your feet. Finally you notice that this pirate, the one that so effortlessly extracted you from your hiding place under the bed, is still holding your ankle.

This seems to snap you back into reality. You kick reflexively, freeing your ankle from his grasp, which had grown slack during your extended contemplation. 'Thomas!' you remember suddenly.

Ignoring the pirates again, you half crawl and half stumble across the room towards the bodies. 'Thomas really is dead!' you force yourself to admit. Still crawling on the floor, you go behind the captain's desk, retrieving from a drawer a small pair of scissors and a little glass vial with a cork. You kneel in front of Thomas, your dearly beloved and now dearly departed friend, and cut one of the golden-brown locks of hair, putting the strands in the jar and carefully replacing the cork. 'I will put it in a piece of jewelry,' you think, placing the vial in the pocket bag tied to the sash of your dress. Then you sit on the floor, still looking at his body.

You can feel the eyes of the pirates watching you. Suddenly the most important thing is survival. It occurs to you that they are waiting for you to say something. 'Quick!' you command yourself, 'Think of something to say! Something important! Some reason that they should let you live, and, more importantly, let you live unmolested.'

"I can play the violin," you hear yourself say in a very small, childish voice.

The dark man looks at you oddly. "Who are you?" he repeats.
1111112.title: The Long Quiet

choices: Hugo will cut your throat if you try that again!
Hugo thinks it is funny how weak you are.
11111121.content:
"Catalina Sherwood," you reply. "Umm, are you going to kill me?"

The smaller of the pirates looks surprised at your bluntness, but the handsome pirate begins to laugh. "Now, why would I want to kill a cute little thing like you?" he asks.

You pause for a moment, trying to calm your nerves so your voice won't tremble, but pretend that you are really thinking about an answer. "Well, you killed everyone else, didn't you?"

"Did you hear that, Hugo?" the smaller pirate said with a laugh. "She thinks YOU killed everyone."

"I'm flattered, little girl," Hugo responds to you, "but I can't take all of the credit myself."

With a foolish courage fueled by your anger at the loss of all of your friends, you struggle to your feet and punch Hugo as hard as you can. Of course, it doesn't hurt him. He grabs both of your wrists in one of his meaty hands so you can't repeat the action.
11111121.title: Honesty?

choices: Trust Hugo
Demand to know the plan
111111211.content:
With your hands immobile in Hugo's grip, you realize that your initial urge to rebel is completely foolish. "Careful, girl!" he hisses, loud enough for the other pirates to hear. They snigger at your helplessness. "You don't fling yourself at men with knives, hasn't anyone ever told you that?" For the first time you notice the mean-looking dagger on Hugo's left hip ... and even more upsetting, the long-barrelled pistol on his right. Catalina is stunned at the idea of being considered a spoil. "I'll not go with you!" she exclaims, increasing her struggling.

Hugo adjusts his hold so Catalina's struggles are even more futile. "That won't be easy," the other pirate stated, "Unless you're willing to share her..."

You awaken lying on the hard wooden planks of the pirate ship. Sitting up you see a few barrels and rope strewn around the small room. There are no windows and the only door appears to be locked. Scared you realise that these pirates are capable of anything. Your life is in their hands. Perhaps it would be better you were dead than to be used anyway these thugs saw fit. On your feet now you stare around your small prison. Searching for anything that may help you escape either the ship or this unfortunate fate. There appears to be no way out. The door refuses to budge, the floor beneath you is probably the only thing stopping you from sinking into the oceans depths. You sink back down to your knees. "It's useless," you think to yourself. You raise your eyes to the roof above you and begin to pray to the God's to keep you safe when you notice that some of the boards are different. In fact, taking a better look you see hinges. "Thankyou," you whisper, smiling in disbelief as you realise that it is a trap door to the deck.

His blond hair is a mess and his clothes are drenched. This is when you notice that the room you are in is tilting and moving in a truly nausous manner. Your face turns green as you try to hold in your supper. 112.content:
This is your father's ship you remember. You have a duty to fulfill. Run and hide, ridiculous! A true Sherwood would never do so. You push your doubts aside and hold your head up, staring into the wind, facing the oncoming ship.

The ship stops about forty feet distant. A cannon is set off, vibrating the air, causing your heart to beat violently. You realize from where you are standing in the shadow of the cabin, and the position of the pirate vessel, you are not easily seen and your ship appears deserted. Perhaps they will believe the entire crew has suffered some disease you think, but quickly brush that thought aside.

Keeping to the shadows, you slip down to the captain's quarters where Thomas and the captain and talking in angry tones debating what is to be done. You hesitate outside the door a moment and enter without knocking.

They stop at your appearance. You've never come to the captain's quarters uninvited before.

"What do they want?" you ask.

"Right now, they are waiting for someone to appear up top," the captain replied with the dignity due to the daughter of the ship's owner. "Thomas here wants to attack now, while they are unprepared, which is folly. They'd cut us to piece in minutes."

"There's always a chance," Thomas spoke up.

"Pirate ships are well armed, always", you speak up attempting to speak with authority. "We will go speak with them and seek their demands."

Thomas and the captain look at you. "I'll follow in a minute," the captain says gruffly after a pause. "Wait in the hall."

As you close the door you hear the concersation resume with a different topic.

"You can't mean to let her go with you!", you hear Thomas cry greatly agitated.

"Having her up there may be the only card we have, of course, I'll let her go."

You realize the captain is not thinking at all of your safety, or where you position should have placed you- firmly under guard- but is only thinking of his survival. That's alright, you tell yourself, you have the same thing in mind, but perhaps going up with the captain in full light isn't the best idea.

A lone man is standing on the deck.

You swallow, and call out, "What is it that you want?"

He starts and peers intently at hearing a woman's voice.

You remain motionless waiting for a reply, allowing him to get over his shock. "What is it that you want?" you repeat when he doesn't answer.

"Who are you?" a harsh, but faintly gentile did answer.

You hold your head up with family pride, "I am the daugher of the owner of this ship, and who are you and what is the purpose of your ship in hindering my father's ship in it's journey to America?"

"I am Hugo of the BlackLonder's Ship, he replied. We wish to board your ship."

You notice the captain who has yet to speak has begun to look worried perhaps at your boldness, your defiance, his lack of authority in this exchange, or perhaps at the entire situation.

"Get away from me, vermin!" You cry as you shove Hugo aside.
You attempt to run, but Hugo grabs your arm and forces you to keep still. Hugo smiles wickedly, as if to somehow imply that the fact that you are weaker than he is amuses him.
Looking into the pirate's face, you realize that you will never be able to escape him by fighting him alone, he is much too strong and could easily break your neck. You realize that your cunning, however, just might save you.

112122112.content:
(Note to Author: I'm sorry about this but I can't write in the manner that you have started but would like to write an add on to this story, so I will write it in the way that I am used to, please except it.)

Jerking hard against my arm, he lead me toward the bottom of the ship. Before he opened the door, he spun me around to face him.

"If I had it my way, I'd do what I wanted then be rid of ya." He told me, breath as bad as a rotten egg, I turned my face to keep from smelling it, but was jerked back around to face him. "But seeing that your of use to us, Maybe we can have our fun later." He put his hand on my leg and I shoved it off.

"Pig." I stated, He opened the door and shoved me inside.

"Until later luv." He grinned and shut the door, laughing as he walked away.

I stood there a little releaved that I was away from him, but not sure of what else I was in store for, I turned around to see two other men, one that was badly hurt and the other who looked scared to death. I walked over to them.

"David?" I asked touching his shoulder, he jerked out of his trance and stared at me.

"Miss Sherwood?" he asked, "Your alive, I was so worried that they had killed you."

"No I'm alright, but what about him?" I asked looking at the other man laying there. David moved closer to him.

"I don't think he's going to make it miss." He told me. "They really beat him, I couldn't stop them, and now they are going to kill us all."

"I don't think so David, they need me alive to get a ransom from my father." I told him as I stood up and walked back over to the door. "Until my father pays, I'm safe, after that..."

On top in the captains room Hugo was looking over the charts as Jacob walked in, his right hand man.

"She's down with the rest Captain." He told him.

"I've told you before not to call me that, I'm not your bloody Captain." Huga stated as he glared at him. "Do it again and you'll find yourself over board with the sharks, got that?"

"Alright, alright." Jacob nodded, then changed the subject, "So what's the plan, I know you want a ransom for the filly, but how are you going to go about getting it?"

"Send a message to the girls father." Hugo told him than sat down in the big chair. "Let him know that if he doesn't pay we'll chop his daughter and fly her skin from the crows nest, only a fool will not pay." He smiled at him.
Jacob returned the smiled and left the room, Hugo sat there thinking about Catalina for a few minutes then reached for a quil and began to write out what was needed to get the attention of her father. When he was satisfide with what he wrote he got up and headed outside on deck.
"Jacob take us out to sea, You there," He pointed to another man, "Get this message off as soon as possable, make it quick, then meet us in Port Castings due west." He smiled, the man took off and head out on the other ship.

After what seemed forever, the door was opened again and there stood Jacob once more.
"Your wanted by Hugo." He told me. "Come along and don't put up a fight, I'd hate to have to take you there dead." He grinned. I sighed and stood up going out of the room after taking a quick glance toward David. Heading back up to the captains chamber, I went inside with Jacob standing behind me.

"Leave us Jacob." Hugo told him, he smiled and patted my backside, I quickly shoved his hand away. "Your diffently a fisty one."

"Why are you doing this?" I asked him as he stood up and walked around the desk toward me.

"Why do you think?" he asked in return.

"Because your a cold hearted bastard." I stated when he stopped in front of me.

"I'm not as cold hearted as you may think, I do have a soft side." He told me, "If I didn't, you would be dead right now, so think about that."

My life my have been in danger but my mind couldn't keep from thinking about how deep blue his eye's were and how the curve of his chin made me feel deep inside. His shirtless chest wasn't helping me at that point, my mind kept wandering as he stood so close to me that I could feel his every breath. He turned and walked away, Leaving me time to breath again and to keep from thinking the thoughs that I was having of him at the moment.

"When your father receives the message of your capture, they will bring down every ship that they have for your safe return." He smiled, "How much does your father really love you?"

"As much as any other father." I told him.

"I guess your the lucky one, I never knew my father." He walked back toward me and slowly circle around, touching my hair with his hand as he spoke. "Maybe that's why I turned out this way. Maybe if things had been different, I wouldn't be standing here right now." He stopped behind me as he picked up a lock of my hair and smelt it, taking in the sweet scent, then letting it drop back down. "But then again maybe I would." he came around to face me once more.

"Why do you do this?" I asked.

"Profit my dear, it all boils down to money, that's every pirates dream, to make that big score, then go for another." He smiled. "Your my big score on this one, I'm sure your father will pay hamsomly to get you back, and with a ship this grand, it can only mean that your swimming in wealth and I want a chunk of it."

"I'll give you a chunk of something." I stated then rushed toward him, he grabbed me and slammed me down on top of the desk. "let me go." I yelled.

"This is going to be an interesting trip." He grinned then bent down forcefully kissing me, I pushed at his chest then weaked for a single moment as I took the kiss he was giving me, when he eased up, I shoved him backwards standing up as I did.

1121221122.content:
Hugo's once-clear blue eyes clouded over. His jaw set and he grabbed Catalina's arm. Before she could cry out, he said to her, "Let me show you something, Miss Moneyknickers."

She could feel the strength in his iron grasp as he led her up the stairs, to the portside deck. She knew he could grip her with much more force, if he wanted. His hands were hardened with a lifetime of callouses from hard work. He held her just tightly enough; she wasn't going anywhere.

The sun was sharp and hot on her fair face as they reached topside. The first thing Catalina noticed as her eyes adjusted was how utterly calm the seas were. the second thing she noticed was how quiet the pirate's ship was.

As if reading her thoughts, Hugo asked, "Hear that, Miss Spoiled? No? Then let's take you closer to all the action."

He bustled her around the corner, as if she were weightless, towards the bow of the ship. There, she could see her beloved ship listing severely to the starboard side. The once-beautiful boat was shattered and smoldering. Catalina remained quiet, but tears filled her own blue eyes as she thought of the crew -- her friends. How many lay dead or dying onboard?

She could see a dozen or more pirates throwing objects overboard, to be caught by the greedy scoundrels in the rafts below. It was a pillage most thorough.

"Gideon's Osprey," she whispered, "may she and her crew rest in peace." Catalina closed her eyes and bowed her head in prayer.

"Aye," Hugo said somberly, and let his own head fall, "'twas a fair ship, with a goodly crew. Tis a pity."

Catalina gave the savage renegade a sideways glance; how odd it was for him to say such a thing. Maybe he wasn't completely vulgar, after all.

Her momentary lapse in hatred for this man was dispelled when her held her shoulders and looked into her eyes from a scant breath away, "Now listen to me, lass. Ye may not like me, and you'd be surely right to fear me, but this doesn't have to be as god-awful as ye might think. After Daddy gives us your weight in gold, we'll be happy to plop you on any dock of yer choosin'. Then ye can be off to bathe in satin and pearls, or whatever it is rich girls do these days. But know ye this: you'd be wise to respect us, for any lip you give will likely get fattened."

At any other time, Catalina might have bristled at being threatened, pirate or not, but the day had brought too much violence and misery upon her. She nodded silently and cried.

Hugo watched her a moment, then made sure the captain wasn't watching. He lifted her quivering chin with one grubby thumb and whispered, "You'll be fine."

11322.content:
Catalina's fine upbringing had steered her every choice in life away from altercations of all sorts; usually there were men around to take care of the unmentionable things outside of her realm -- men paid by Daddy. Catalina looked wildly from her left to her right, hoping to catch sight of Daddy's men rushing to her aid.

The only thing she saw was a cloud of flaming debris that filled the air as another cannon blew apart some of the mast. Those bloody heathens were destroying Daddy's ship!

Catalina heard the terrible sounds of battle wash over her: the blasts of gunfire, the crash of the cannons, the shrill ringing of swords that clashed for control of the small ship. But most importantly, and sounds that would be ingrained into Catalina's memories for all time, she heard the screams of men dying. It was almost as if their last breaths took away hers as well. It was all too clear to the young heiress that there would be no men to rescue her.

She was on her own.

Prisoner aboard a pirate vessel was an image that also took the air from her lungs. How many weeks -- or months -- would she be trapped, adrift, until her father's men could track her down and pay the inevitable ransom? Or better yet, rescue her and set the brigand ship ablaze to watch it sink to the bottom of the ocean? A shudder coursed through her skin as she reckoned what those filthy bastards would do to her in the meantime.

"Unhand me," she tried to yell but fear had constricted her vocal cords to a whisper. She could smell this beastly man's slimy sweat on her cheek and in her hair. She wanted to cry but was unable to find the tears. Instead she stomped her heeled shoe down into the pirate's instep, making him yelp and flinch enough to give Catalina the instant for which she'd been waiting. She threw herself from the blue-eyed man's grasp and dashed along the wet and smoking topside deck, away from him.

113222.content:
Catalina knew the layout of the ship and thought that would give her an advantage over the attackers so she might stay a step ahead of them, and -- hopefully -- stay alive. But her eyes were useless in the heavy black smoke that seeped from below decks like blood through a bandage. Her ship was dying surely enough, and it seemed destined to take her down with it. Her shoes: good, sensible shoes befitting an educated young lady such as herself, were ill-suited for a death race aboard a listing ship, and twice her feet slid out from under her and she crashed into debris strewn about the ship. Finally Catalina grit her teeth and pulled the shoes from her sore and bleeding feet and got to running once more.

But running to where? What would she do when she reached the rear of the ship? Or the bow? Or below decks? There was really nowhere to hide, but to her terrified mind there was only one solitary thought of which she was consciously aware: RUN!

And run she did -- right into the chest of a half-naked, creosote-covered black-heart that knocked her again to her backside with a jarring THUMP! Her teeth snapped closed, narrowly missing her tongue, and her eyes wandered as her dizzy head spun like a top inside her skull. Catalina was just clearing the cobwebs when the brute closed one massive paw along her jawline and picked her up to peer into her face.

He exposed all three remaining teeth when he sneered, "Hey! What's dis then? HA! A woman!"

Catalina still clutched both of her shoes in her hands, and the soles of them, she knew, were as deadly as any weapon ever wielded by any man. She spread her arms wide, and this unexpected maneuver made the damned pirate pause to look at her actions with two dimwitted eyes, right before she swung her arms together as if she were crashing a cymbal instead of a man's skull.

He cried out and threw Catalina down, whereupon she landed hard against a large piece of railing. It did not puncture her back and embed itself into her kidneys like the pain indicated it had, but it was certainly enough to forcibly drive the air from her lungs in a sickly wheeze. There appeared to be two of him as she looked up, and neither was any better looking than the other.

1132222.content:
Catalina had spent much of her life ensconced in the thick, dusty books of her tutelage, and as such, never had the opportunity to experience an explosion of any sort with any kind of proximity. So when the next cannon ball tore through the main mast and skipped off the deck before striking the man in front of her and sending his body into the sea, she was amazed at the power of the concussion of air as the enormous projectile passed by. The displacement of which twisted her lungs and made Catalina involuntarily retch. Thousands of deadly wood splinters tore through the air in search of something soft to pierce. She wanted to duck but her world seemed oddly lacking in gravity, or a clearly defined sense of up and down for that matter, and instead her head lashed uncontrollably from one side to the other as wooden shrapnel pelted her.

Had she hit her head? Why was she unable to focus?

Catalina fought the nausea to see the huge main mast twisting free of the ship not twenty feet to her right. And though it occurred to her that she needed to roll or crawl away as it teetered above her, her ragged body was too wobbly to react. She could only keep still on her back and watch as the giant wooden cylinder broke free of the myriad of rigging that temporarily slowed its free fall and would soon become her tomb.
1132222.title: Her assailant becomes cannon fodder

choices: Catalina succumbs to the action & passes out
She thanks the pirate for saving her life
11322221.content:
And just like that her swirling world upended and her body felt weightless. The vertiginous feeling was gone, replaced only with a strong sensation of floating.

Had she died? Had the main mast crushed her so thoroughly that she never felt any pain, and was currently on her way to the afterlife?

The answer was a resounding NO as her limp little body crashed back to the deck with something heavy wrapped around her. She rolled over some rope, which burned her shoulders, and a random nail came perilously close to her eyes, but Catalina had no time to register this because it was at that very instant when the mast crashed into the deck with a destructive force a hundred times that of the cannon ball just a few moments ago. It tore into the ship and crashed through the decks on its way through the hull and, eventually, to the very bottom of the ocean. The ship screamed as the structural integrity gave out and the vessel suddenly turned on itself, collapsing inwardly as water surged upwards through the boat with great tenacity and inevitability, causing the ship's screams to turn to groans, almost as if it were aware of its fast-approaching demise and accepted it with little more than sad moans.

"Girl!"

What? What was that?

"Girl! Are you injured?"

Suddenly, Catalina's strained consciousness allowed her to focus on her surroundings once again, and she realized she was wrapped in the protective cover of two masculine arms. She wriggled free and fell to her chin. When she looked up, she stared again into the bluest eyes she had ever seen, the eyes of the first pirate that she'd stomped.

"You!"

He sat up and quickly looked around. Catalina's ship was breaking apart and already the frothy sea was coming up to meet them through the extensive damage of the boat. "Are you injured?" he asked.

"I don't, I don't --"

"Can you walk?"

Again, her mouth betrayed her with unintelligible stutters, "I, I don't --"

The man clenched his jaw beneath his lips and swooped one arm around Catalina's waist as if her were carrying a puppy. He sprinted over flaming wreckage as easily as one might skip across the sidewalk on a lovely spring day, only with a hundred-pound girl on his hip. He got to the remains of the outer rail and put one shiny boot on it. He leaned over and shouted, "McShay! McShay, throw me a line, for the love of God!"

Catalina's dazed state kept her from knowing the precise actions of her savior, but there was a thump as he caught something in his chest. Rope, maybe? Then the weightless feeling returned as the man swung them across to the other boat, the sinister one, whereupon they were pulled from the air by rough hands, one of which found Catalina's breast.

You cannot believe it has been two years since that day on the Maestro, yet you stand on the edge of the dock, your eyes searching the sea beyond for a glimpse of the ship that will bear you home. After the massacre aboard that ship, you awoke in the kitchen, your head swimming with hazy memories. A voice called out in the din. You tried to answer but your voice seemed lost. A British naval ship had arrived.

It seemed as though the pirate you had come in contact with had rendered you unconscious and left you for dead below deck. When the soldiers brought you out, fallen sailors littered the starboard side as other British servicemen piled them high. You did not see Thomas's body. The fleet sailed straight back to London and from there you sent a letter home. For safety precautions, you remained in London, serving as a governess for a local merchant's children.

Now, however, your family considered it safe to return to the States, and you calmly await the vessel that will bear you hence.

Many changes...You remember a time when appearances and stature mattered to you, only 2 years ago. Now, even as a proper teacher for proper English children you find yourself drifting from the everyday and gazing back to the sea, remembering the day you started to believe in fate.

You break your gaze with the sea and cock your head to the side as you hear a familiar voice call your name.

"Oiy! Catalina, and where dew ya think yar goin'?"

You smile as you recognize Caleb O'Sullivan's jaunty call.

"Far and away, Caleb, far and away," you sigh as you turn to face him.

Caleb was the soldier who had found you in the ship's kitchen that terrible day. A career soldier and sailor, Caleb had been your best friend for the last 24 months and despite everyone's best wishes that the two of you wed, the relationship stayed strangely platonic.

"Yar no thinkin' 'o goin' back out dere, are ya?"
Caleb jokingly asked, nudging your shoulder.

"What? And leave you to all these poor barmaiden's? Not on your life, Irish!"
You quip, snatching the sailor's hat off his head and placing it on yours.

"Now Cat, ah know yer family wants ya ta come home and awl, bet ah still think it's no safe,"
he says seriously, leaning against the railing and looking sharply at you.

"I highly doubt those same pirates are in any way after me, Caleb," you reply, "Besides, he left me for dead. Do you really think I even matter to them? For God's sake, Irish, I'm just one girl out of a million they've terrified."

"Ya are one in 'o million, Cat," Caleb said, looking out at the ocean. "Yar ma best friend, and ah don't wan ana-thing ta happen to ya."

Caleb places his hands firmly on your shoulder's and looks you squarely in the eyes.

"Remember, it's no tha weapon thas impartant, but the one who wields et," he says.

You nod and wrap your arms around his waist, laying your head on his chest as he follows suit.

"I will remember,"
you promise.

Caleb holds you for a moment longer, despite the stares of other passengers and sailors, then releases you, patting the hat on your head.

"Keep a sharp eye,"
he mutters, bowing deeply before dashing off the dock towards the fort.
1212111111.title: Sharp Blades And Sharper Eyes

choices: In your cabin

12121111111.content:
You spend the next couple hours leaning over the starboard side, squeezing your eyes shut and swallowing hard. After 2 years of only being on pleasure boats in the bay with Irish, she hadn't quite gotten her sea-legs yet, or for that matter, stomach. She wasn't alone however; most of the other passengers on the Saint Cleary were English patrons who'd never sailed in their lives, and were equally wrong-footed.

"You don't look half as ill as the rest of us,"
a groggy voice commented as you raised your head from over the side.

A girl with stringy blond hair, a couple years your senior smiles tremulously at you, slightly green. You chuckle.

"Well, I've learned to keep it down,"
you reply, wiping your sweating forehead.

"Saw you with that soldier back there on the deck-is he your man?"
She asked.

You can't help but laugh.
"No, he's not my...he's naught but a very good friend of mine," you muse. "He's been taking good care of me these last years. Are you always so observant?"

"Usually," she shrugged,"but only when it comes to things of that nature. The name's Katherine Hart."

"Catalina Sherwood."

"Sounds like a rich, red wine. Anyone ever tell you that?"

"Many, considering that's what my father named me after. Said my momma drank so much of it, was bound to be born looking like this," you said, running your fingers through your damp red curls.

Katherine smiled wryly. Suddenly, she was all business.

"They say it'll be a long trip, couple weeks to a month. What say you to being my company?"
She asked, kind of shyly but still confident.

You pretend to mull it over for a moment. Then you grin.

"Why not? Two young girls like ourselves should not be left alone for such a time," you remark, preening importantly.

"Good. Well, I'm going to get ready for dinner. Meet me there? You can meet my family, then."

"Alright. See you there, Miss Hart."

And she left with a flounce of skirts and wiggling of her fingers. Your smile faded as you turned and looked out to sea. A faint spot on the horizon, near the setting sun, caught your eye. You blink, then eye it suspiciously.
12121111111.title: Sea-Side Meet & Greet

choices: Katherine wakes you

The sun was set, and dinner was served. You spent your time there eating sparingly, for the feeling chewing up your insides was not hunger. Plus, you could tell that despite your excellent references as a schoolmarm, Katherine's rich and hoity-toity family did not care for you. You stayed for only 20 minutes before retiring to your cabin.

As you sat on the bed, you reached into your pocket and retrieved your soldier's parting gift. It really was a very well-made blade, and you shuddered to think what he paid to get it to you. No matter, it was for use. Hoping dearly you wouldn't need to use it anytime soon, you slipped it under your pillow and lay down in your clothes, one eye open towards the sea out your port window...

You headed for the door, and as you wrenched it open, another scream echoes through the hall and someone goes rushing past, pursued by another. The pursuer stops suddenly and whirls at you. Steeling your nerves, you face the sweaty, unshaven mass that is indeed a pirate. He grins sichophantically at you as he advances to your door. You stand still, hoping he cannot hear your beating heart through your breast. He makes to grab your arm...

...when your knee suddenly connects with his groin, and moaning he sinks to the floor, woozy, but still alert. He growls, but your fist plows into his face. His eyes whirl for a moment, then close as he passes out before you. You purse your lips as you dash from your cabin and out into the hall, following the shrieks and clanging metal.

Squinting through the hazy fog that seems to have followed the pirates onboard, you silently climb the stairs to top deck. Sounds of metal on metal, and dying groans meet your ears. The terrified scream blasts the din once more and you can make out the forms of people running across the deck.

"Get the women below, Jeremy, hurry!"
A commanding voice cried.

As you hurry towards the voice, something heavy lands at your feet. A sailor, more than likely this Jeremy, the firstmate, lies bleeding from the head and unmistakably dead. Silently praying for his immortal soul, you gank the short-sword from his cold fingers and peer across the deck.

"Catalina! Run!"
A terrified shriek...Katherine Hart.

A greasy, scabby-looking toughie has his arm around her neck and a blade to her side. Growling with anger, you charge at him. He looks quite surprised, but pushes Katherine aside, raising his sword. As he raises it high, you dive low and force your blade into his thigh, a low blow, but a lifesaving one for him. He drops his sword as he howls with pain, and you uppercut, slamming your elbow into his chin and he falls back against the bow, tumbling over with a small splash.

choices: Bitch her overboard
take her below
121211111111212.content:
Smiling to yourself, you adjust your stance and look down at Katherine. But she is not looking to you, instead her eyes are fastened on a point behind you. Slowly, you turn around. Out in the fog, about mid-deck, another pirate appears before you, but he is not fighting, his eyes are on you. Your hand clutches the sword tighter as your eyes adjust to the dark, and suddenly, to your horror, you recognize him...

...Eyes as blue as the sea after a storm. The pirate who, to be quite honest, had saved your life. That meant, however, that these were the same pirates who attacked the Maestro, leaving everyone aboard dead. The pirate looked just as shocked to see you as you did him, especially at the sight of you holding a sword. You shake yourself out of your reverie and grab Katherine's arm. If you don't get her off this ship, she will surely die.

Eyes still on the pirate, you whisper to her.
"Katherine, I want you to do exactly as I say and do nothing different, do you understand?"

A whimper assurred you her unwavering obedience. You watched the pirate warily, but he did nothing to stop you. Indeed, he seemed to be motioning to the ocean behind you with his beautiful blue eyes.

All she could think of was to keep rowing. "Must keep rowing, must keep rowing!" She muttered to herself. She felt as the boat tipped to the side, but it would come back, then tip to the other side.

After a few minutes, of trying to control the boat enough to keep rowing, one of the oars was jerked from her hand, and it flew out to the ocean. She tried to row with only one oar, but it became an exremely difficult, to the point where it became almost impossible to row. 12121121122211111111111121111121111.content:
Catalina sat there for a little longer, glaring at Hugo. He simply smiled playfully back at her. She accepted the challenge.
With a deep breath, she let the blanket fall and got to her feet. Fearing to look at Hugo's face, she held her head high and and walked over to the clothes line. She grabbed her undergarments and quickly pulled then on, her back to Hugo. When she turned around, fully clothed, Hugo was holding out some food for her. She took it and sat down on the opposite side of the fire.
"Now is that any way to treat the man you spent the night with?" he said, grinning from ear to ear.
"You said...!" Catalina cried, jumping to her feet.
"I was only playing with you!" Hugo laughed. "Please, sit down. Nothing happened, I promise," he put his hand on his heart. Catalina was strangely aware of the fact that he was half-naked. She pulled her eyes away from him and back down to her food.
"What about the ship?" Catalina asked after a long silence.
"It's waiting offshore," he pointed, and surely enough, there it was, its anchor thrown into the now calm sea. "When we are ready to go, we may rejoin the crew. It's all up to you, my lady."

121211211222111111111111211111211112.content:
Catalina gazed at the ship, then back at Hugo. "I haven't even finished my breakfast yet."
"Of course, my lady," Hugo smiled knowingly.
As Catalina ate her food, her memory slowly came back. Her last conversation with Hugo. He had intended to send her back to America. He had decided to leave her. Anything that she thought he might have felt...
She glanced up at him. He was focussed on eating his food, but his brow was creased, as if he were thinking the same thoughts as she. She had gotten into that boat with the intention of never seeing him again, of forgetting about him. But could she? There he was, so incredibly carefree, so full of life. He seemed to know more of life then anyone she knew. Part of her wanted to know what he knew, to become a part of this life. But she also had duty, to her father, she had responsibilities.
"When we do get back aboard the ship, will you send me back to America?" she asked.
Hugo looked up at her, his eyes clouded. "If that's what you want, then yes, we will."
"What do you mean, if that's what I want?"
He shrugged. "If you want to return to your old life, then I won't be the one to stop you."
"Of course I do, why would I want to stay?" Catalina replied hastily.
Hugo looked hurt, but just nodded. Catalina wondered if she should ask him if there was a reason she should stay.

121211212.content:
Catalina sat still on the bed for awhile, taking in all that had happened to her in such a short period of time. Her life was now in danger and she knew that, if she were to survive, it would be completely up to her and how cunning she could be. But she was only a twenty year old girl, a teacher. How would she be able to come up with something clever enough to outwit a gang of pirates?

As she looked around the room she noticed that the door was slightly ajar and led out into the now empty hallway. She wondered if, in a ship full of blood thirsty pirates, she would be able to find someone who could sympathize with her situation. There had to be someone on this humongous ship who had a heart.

Slowly, carefully, she made her way towards the door and pushed it open even farther. It made a loud creaking noise and she froze in fear for a moment. When no one came running, she slipped out into the hallway and started to make her way up the stairs. I'm almost there, she thought. Just up these stairs and maybe I'll be able to find some help.

Catalina stopped when she reached the top of the stairs. The door in front of her led to the deck, where all the pirates were probably lounging. If she were to open the door and start pleading her case, one of them might feel sorry for her. Or, they might all hate her and decide to kill her right then. She had to make a decision now, or else wait and let her fate rest in the hands of these grungy pirates.

She swung open the door and gasped when she saw the pirate called Hugo standing there with his arms folded across his chest staring straight at her. His gaze sent shivers up her spine, but she refused to look weak. Holding her head high, she addressed him in as calm and strong a voice as she could muster. "I would like to go with you."

"Excuse me?"

"You heard me, I'd like to go with you wherever it is you are going."

A smirk spread across Hugo's face and Catalina realized just how handsome he actually was. Dark hair and dark eyes framed his tan skin and she also couldn't help but notice how muscular he was and how wonderfully his barely-there shirt looked on him. She swallowed hard and made herself look the handsome pirate in the eye.

122.content:
The pirate ship was approaching fast. Catalina was afraid, but also felt a wild kind of excitement. What would happen next?
The captain bellowed, "All hands on deck!" He noticed Catalina and said, "This is not a time for ladies to be taking a stroll on deck. You need to be in your quarters. I don't need a fainting woman on my hands."
Catalina indignantly placed her hands on her hips, her eyes blazing as she snapped a reply, "I am NOT a fainting woman. I'll thank you not to judge a person's character just by glancing at them."
The captain viewed Catalina with less contempt, but not quite the respect she was demanding. "Spitfire, aren't ya. Well, it'll do you no good with those pirates. They favor the spirited ones - more fun in a challenge."
Catalina pretended to be shocked as the captain moved down the deck towards his crewman. But secretly, she felt a little thrill at the thought of fighting off a deadly pirate and winning.
The captain turned back around. "If you stay, you'll have to help with the rigging - I can't have a useless body flapping about the deck.
Catalina's temper flared. "Show me what I need to do." Her anger giving her strength, she stormed over to a grab a rope from a surprised sailor and worked with the men to get another sail up.
The captain chuckled. "That's a woman like I've never seen."

1222.content:
The ship approached, cutting through the waves with the ease and grace of a swan on water. Down below the crew were springing into action, each with their specific duty and zigzagging around the other comrades as they hurriedly readied the ship for battle.

Glancing over to the advancing frigate the deck was empty. There was not the hustle and bustle of their own ship but an eerie stillness.

Entranced by the crew-less ship Catalina overlooked the urgent shouts of the men above her and with a fleeting look upwards, recognised the yardarm falling towards her. She swang out of the way but too late, the wooden beam came crashing to the deck, with a startled Catalina entangled in the splintered timber and frayed ropes.

'Catalina?' Thomas was at her side almost immediately, concern filled his eyes.

She could just about make out his brown mop of hair framing his face but he grew dimmer and the reply wasn't able to leave her lips.

'Catalina,' he repeated, 'Keep calm, you've sustained a wound to your leg.'

A wound? Looking down she could see the shard of the yardarm sticking out of her leg and her head began to swim.

'Catalina! Stay with me now.' Thomas urged, 'You there! Jim, Garrett! Take this girl to the carpenter's cabin. She'll need this out before infection. Quick!'
1222.title: Man Down

choices: to give over all goods aboard the ship
